Hint: Ensures <li> elements are used semantically
Description: All list items (<li>) must be contained within  <ul> or <ol> parent elements.

Hint: Ensure that lists are structured correctly
Description: Lists must be marked up correctly, meaning they must not contain content elements other than <li> elements.

Hint: id attribute value must be unique
Description: The value assigned to the id="" attribute must be unique to prevent the second instance from being overlooked by assistive technology. Put another way, id attributes may not be used more than once in the same document in order to differentiate each element from another.

Hint: Elements must have sufficient color contrast
Description: All text elements must have sufficient contrast between text in the foreground and background colors behind it in accordance with WCAG 2 AA contrast ratio thresholds.

Hint: Certain ARIA roles must be contained by particular parents
Description: Certain ARIA roles must be contained by particular parent roles in order to perform the intended accessibility functions.

Hint: Form elements must have labels
Description: Each form element must have a programmatically associated label element.

Hint: Links must have discernible text
Description: Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) must be discernible by a screen reader, must not have a duplicate label, and must be focusable.

Hint: Ensure that each non-empty data cell in a large table has one or more table headers
Description: Data table markup can be tedious and confusing. It is important that it is done semantically and with the correct header structure. Screen readers have a number of features to make table navigation easier, but tables must be marked up accurately for these features to work properly.

Hint: <audio> elements must have a captions track
Description: For each HTML 5 <audio> element, the <track> element must be present, with kind="captions" set as a property. Captions are text—synchronized with the audio file—of the dialog, narration, and any important auditory information, for the benefit of deaf users.

Hint: Ensure <dl> elements are structured correctly
Description: Definition lists (<dl>) must contain only properly-ordered <dt> and <dd> groups, <script> or <template> elements.

Hint: <dt> and <dd> elements must be contained by a <dl>
Description: Definition list items (<dt> and/or <dd>) must be wrapped in parent <dl> elements to be valid. This enables screen reader users to understand the proper hierarchy of information in the list.

Hint: <html> element must have a lang attribute
Description: The HTML document must contain a valid lang attribute or must correspond to a valid lang code for multilingual screen reader users who may prefer a language other than the default.

Hint: <html> element must have a valid value for the lang attribute
Description: The HTML document must contain a valid lang attribute or must correspond to a valid lang code for multilingual screen reader users who may prefer a language other than the default.

Hint: Ensure <marquee> elements are not used
Description: <marquee> elements must not be present because they are deprecated, increase difficulty for users with limited dexterity, and are distracting for users with cognitive or attention deficits.

Hint: <object> elements must have alternate text
Description: All embedded objects must have text alternatives to be read out to screen reader users.

Hint: <video> elements must have captions
Description: An HTML5 <video> element must include a <track> element with kind="captions" set as a property. The captions should convey all meaningful auditory information in the video including dialogue, musical cues, sound effects, and other relevant information for deaf users.

Hint: <video> elements must have an audio description track
Description: The HTML 5 <video&gt element must have an audio description track to provide blind users with information the dialogue does not.

Hint: aria-hidden="true" must not be present on the document body
Description: When an aria-hidden attribute with a value of 'true' is present in the body of the document, the content won't be accessible to assistive technology.

Hint: accesskey attribute value must be unique
Description: All accesskeys in the document must be unique. Put another way, accesskeys must not be repeated to prevent unexpected effects for keyboard users.

Hint: Table headers in a data table must refer to data cells
Description: Data table markup can be tedious and confusing. It is important that it is done semantically and with the correct header structure. Screen readers have a number of features to make table navigation easier, but tables must be marked up accurately for these features to work properly.

Hint: Ensure that each table header in a data table refers to data cells
Description: Data table markup can be tedious and confusing. It is important that it is done semantically and with the correct header structure. Screen readers have a number of features to make table navigation easier, but tables must be marked up accurately for these features to work properly.

Hint: ARIA attributes must conform to valid names
Description: ARIA attributes (i.e. starting with aria-) must have valid names. Referring to a misspelled attribute or to one that does not exist will result in an invalid attribute and thus failure of this Rule.

Hint: ARIA attributes must conform to valid values
Description: ARIA attributes (i.e. starting with aria-) must contain valid values. These values must be spelled correctly and correspond to values that make sense for a particular attribute in order to perform the intended accessibility function.

Hint: ARIA roles used must conform to valid values
Description: Values assigned to ARIA roles (role="") must be valid. This means values must be spelled correctly, must correspond to existing ARIA role values, and must not be abstract roles in order to correctly expose the purpose of the element.

Hint: Ensure buttons have discernible text
Description: Buttons must have discernible text that clearly describes the destination, purpose, function, or action for screen reader users.

Hint: Certain ARIA roles must contain particular children
Description: There are some ARIA parent roles that must contain specific child roles to perform their intended accessibility function.

Hint: Data or header cells should not be used to give caption to a data table
Description: Data table markup can be tedious and confusing. Screen readers have a number of features to make table navigation easier, but tables must be marked up accurately for these features to work properly. Some tables use cells with a colspan to visually indicate a caption, instead of using an actual caption element.

Hint: Documents must have <title> element to aid in navigation
Description: The HTML document must have a <title> element to provide users with an overview of its content, and when present, it must not be empty

Hint: Elements must only use allowed ARIA attributes
Description: Not all ARIA role-attribute combinations are valid. This Rule checks that each role is supplied with allowed attributes.

Hint: Elements should not have tabindex greater than zero
Description: A tabindex attribute must never have a value greater than 0 to prevent an unexpected tab order that can give the appearance of skipping some elements entirely.

Hint: Image buttons must have alternate text
Description: When an image is being used as an <input> button, it must have alternate text to allow screen reader users to know its purpose.

Hint: Images must have alternate text
Description: All images must have alternate text to convey their purpose and meaning to screen reader users.

Hint: lang attribute must have a valid value
Description: The language specified in the HTML document must be one of the valid languages to ensure text is pronounced correctly for screen reader users.

Hint: Layout tables must not use data table elements
Description: If a table is being used for layout purposes only, it must not use data table elements such as a header, caption, and summary to prevent confusion by screen reader users who would otherwise expect data to be contained within the cells.

Hint: Page must have means to bypass repeated blocks
Description: Each page must have a <main> landmark to provide a mechanism to bypass repeated blocks of content or interface elements (like header and navigation) and quickly arrive at the main content.

Hint: Required ARIA attributes must be provided
Description: ARIA widget roles must have appropriate attributes describing the state or properties of the widget.

Hint: The page should have a skip link as its first link
Description: The page must have a link at the top (before the navigation) that allows users to skip lengthy navigation and proceed to a page's main content to save time.

Hint: Timed refresh must not exist
Description: "The document must not use <meta http-equiv="refresh"> because it can prevent control over when the refresh occurs for users with disabilities."

Hint: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
Description: The document must not use the user-scalable=no parameter in the <meta name="viewport"> element because it disables text scaling and zooming which is essential to users with low vision.
